bSPDOx-y4.memHandModelNotes: SW Gap project modeled this species without map units using only ancillary data as model components

references.U01GAR01USGP: Garrett, Kimball L. and Ronald L. Walker. 2001. Spotted Dove (Streptopelia chinensis), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/586.

references.FL316: Hardy, John William. Feral exotic birds in southern California. The Wilson Bulletin. 1973; 85(4):506-511.
references.B04UNI01USGP: Unitt, P. 2004. San Diego County Bird Atlas. Proceedings of the San Diego Natural History Museum, 39. 644 pp.

habitat_description: Streptopelia chinensis, which was introduced to California in the early 20th century, inhabits residential areas and urban parks (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Hardy, 1973; Baptista, 1976; McClure, 1992; Garrett and Walker, 2001; Unitt, 2004), typically nesting in tall trees (Willett, 1933; Hardy, 1973) and foraging on the ground in nearby open areas (Garrett and Walker, 2001). In California, the species is generally absent from native woodlands and is restricted to elevations below ~1500 m (Garrett and Walker, 2001). Since the 1980s, populations of spotted dove have declined in California (McClure, 1992; Garrett and Walker, 2001; Unitt, 2004).
